blog.name: conciteque
blog.title: I had a dream…
blog.description:
French fanfic writer, you can find me under the name Milligramme on AO3. I write and post both in French and English (mostly English these days), and I love talking about whatever silly headcanon crossed my mind or anything, really. Enjoy your time here! I'm mostly into BnHA these days, Kiribaku especially, it's taking over my life!
I am also Captain AdachIwai (Adachi/Iwai, from Persona 4 and 5 respectively). Don't hesitate to talk to me about my ships, of whatever you feel like!

tags: conci is obsessed with bnha and speaks German
summary:
My dad: *tries to make me watch a boring crime movie in German so I can practice*
Me: "Class 1-A stumbling upon a boring German...
body:
My dad: *tries to make me watch a boring crime movie in German so I can practice*

Me: “Class 1-A stumbling upon a boring German crime movie, without subtitles, and watching it even though no one has any idea what’s going on”

Kaminari and Sero make memes, Iida is super engrossed, Todoroki genuinely tries to enjoy it, Momo reveals that she speaks some German and tries to explain what is going on even though she only understands bits, Deku doesn’t get why the others are doing it to themselves, Aoyama somehow only picks the swear words like “oui, Scheiße” and Bakugou falls asleep and becomes the attraction for people who don’t care about the movie but don’t want to move either

blog.name: xambedo
blog.title: Ambedo
blog.description: Anime | Manga | Games | Fanfics

summary: [Seeing Stars]
title: [Seeing Stars]
body:
Series: Boku no Hero Academia
Setting: Canon.
Pairing: Kacchako. 

Summary: They say the way to a man’s heart… is through a kick to the head?! 

A/N: I’m pretty behind on the manga right now so I went with a post-internship setting inspired by an experience I had in one of my martial arts classes ^^’  

Uraraka had been training for hours. Katsuki watched from his seat, tucked away behind a screen Yaoyorozu had decorated the lobby with. In order to make space, Uraraka had moved furniture, expanding the area to create a safe distance for combat. It was never his intention to hide, she’d simply overlooked him. 

In hindsight, Katsuki could have offered a hand, probably sped up the process. But then she’d managed on her own and it was too late to say anything about it. She wouldn’t be long, he’d thought. He’d just wait it out. And then suddenly it was curfew and every fibre of his being was itching—exploding—to leave. 

In the end, Katsuki just couldn’t bring himself to go. An out of body experience, one might say, or a genuine desire not to be labelled a pervert like that stupid Mineta. It didn’t matter how beautiful the girls in class were, they wanted to be heroes just like him. He valued strength, not appearance. They were rivals and equals and everything in between. Nothing more; nothing less. 

But, seriously, why was she training alone after curfew? Embarrassment or dedication? And in those little shorts, too. Was she determined to catch a damn cold?

Ugh, Katsuki didn’t care. He just wanted her to leave so he could go to bed. He was exhausted from tutoring Kirishima and yelling at Deku most of the day. He didn’t feel like arguing with or humiliating Uraraka by showing his face right now. Not even Katsuki had that kind of stamina left in him. 

Closing the book in his lap, Katsuki slouched in his seat, legs propped up on an abandoned table. He could see Uraraka through the slits in the wooden screen. Wiping her forehead, she took a loud breath and readied a new stance. Her combat training with Gunhead was really paying off. Though she didn’t yet seem to appreciate it, Uraraka had created a great opportunity to expand on her impressive quirk. Combat allowed her to get in close when necessary, providing better opportunities for touch. She just needed a little confidence. 

Sliding her left leg back, Uraraka prepared another kick. She’d been practising —and struggling—with the same move for a while now. Extending one hand in front of her face, she bounced her back leg, built up a momentum, and then threw it in a clockwise arc. Her stance was too short. The kick struck her open palm, but without the proper stance, Uraraka lost balance quickly. To Katsuki’s surprise, his ever-cheerful classmate let out a low but distinctive curse.

He couldn’t watch this anymore.

“Your stance is too short,” he said, peeking out from behind the screen.

Uraraka screeched like a cartoon mouse baited into a trap. She covered her face to defend against the embarrassment. Katsuki rolled his eyes.

“B-Bakugou, when did you get here?”

“I didn’t,” he said, stepping out from behind the screen. 

“What?” She lowered her hands.

Katsuki cleared his throat. “I’ve been here the whole time…”

Realisation dawned on Uraraka like clouds encompassing the sun. The light faded in her eyes, replaced by sheer horror.

Katsuki offered his hand. She stared long and hard, as though assessing the danger of his palm, and then finally she took it. Once back to her feet, Uraraka’s embarrassment faded, replaced by her usual smile. 

“Here,” he said, gesturing to the empty space in front of him. “Stand with your back to me.”

Uraraka blinked.

“What’re you waitin’ for, a coronation?? Move it!”

“R-right!”

“Now ready your stance.”

Positioned in front of him, Uraraka slid her left leg back until their heels were in line with each other. Katsuki adjusted her hips, straightening her form until her upper body faced the opposing window. Slowly, taking care not to act inappropriately, Katsuki then pulled Uraraka’s leg towards him, lengthening her stance. He kicked the inside of her heel, widening the distance between her feet.

“Turn your feet,” he said, patting her leg. “Point your toes outward for balance.”

Nodding, Uraraka did as she was told. 

Circling around her, Katsuki held up his hand as though offering a handshake. Her new target. “Now kick me.”

Uraraka chewed her lip. “Are you–”

“Kick me, damn it!”

“Here I go! Get ready!”

That’s it. That’s the determination he’d witnessed during the Sports Festival. Adrenaline rushed through him in sparks of anticipation. 

Wait—why were her eyes closed? 

Uraraka’s leg came hard, passing Katsuki’s hand and cracking him in the temple. He smashed into the ground, disorientated, a thousand tiny Deku’s floating obnoxiously around his face. Uraraka appeared in his vision, flushed with apologies.

“I’m so sorry, Bakugou!”

Without thinking, Katsuki reached out for help. She yanked him to his feet—and off them. Katsuki hurtled sideways and upside down. Ah, shit. 

“Hang on! I’ll fix this!” she yelled. 

Before she could end the effects of her quirk, Katsuki kicked off the ceiling, propelling himself right towards her. She opened her arms to catch him. To his surprise, Uraraka took the brunt of his weight, barely staggering backwards. The effects lifted, and Katsuki landed safely on his feet. 

“Are you okay?” she asked.

He blinked, trying to centre the room around him. Damn it all, his head hurt. 

“What were you thinking?” he snapped. “Who closes their eyes during a training session?!”

“S-sorry! I got a little excited…”

Excited? 

“Don’t be sorry. Do better next time.”

“Next time?”

“Tomorrow. We’ll meet again tomorrow.”

Uraraka’s eyes lit up, that same smile widening until it hurt his cheeks to look at it. Katsuki’s heart gave a long and nauseating leap. 

He squeezed her shoulder. “That was a damn good kick,” he praised. “My head is spinning.”

Uraraka’s face ignited like fireworks, those pink cheeks glowing with an amalgam of embarrassment and pride. She rubbed the back of her head, still grinning without a care in the world.

“Let’s give it one more try,” he said. 

Still grinning, Uraraka stepped back into place. Katsuki stated at her, caught in the trance of his own rapid heartbeat. She was glowing. 

“I’ll do my best!”

Katsuki now knew what they meant by “seeing stars”.

Katsuki adjusted her hips, straightening her form until her upper body faced the opposing window. Slowly, taking care not to act inappropriately, Katsuki then pulled Uraraka’s leg towards him, lengthening her stance. He kicked the inside of her heel, widening the distance between her feet.

“Turn your feet,” he said, patting her leg. “Point your toes outward for balance.”

Nodding, Uraraka did as she was told. 

Circling around her, Katsuki held up his hand as though offering a handshake. Her new target. “Now kick me.”

Uraraka chewed her lip. “Are you–”

“Kick me, damn it!”

“Here I go! Get ready!”

That’s it. That’s the determination he’d witnessed during the Sports Festival. Adrenaline rushed through him in sparks of anticipation. 

Wait—why were her eyes closed? 

Uraraka’s leg came hard, passing Katsuki’s hand and cracking him in the temple. He smashed into the ground, disorientated, a thousand tiny Deku’s floating obnoxiously around his face. Uraraka appeared in his vision, flushed with apologies.

“I’m so sorry, Bakugou!”

Without thinking, Katsuki reached out for help. She yanked him to his feet—and off them. Katsuki hurtled sideways and upside down. Ah, shit. 

“Hang on! I’ll fix this!” she yelled. 

Before she could end the effects of her quirk, Katsuki kicked off the ceiling, propelling himself right towards her. She opened her arms to catch him. To his surprise, Uraraka took the brunt of his weight, barely staggering backwards. The effects lifted, and Katsuki landed safely on his feet. 

“Are you okay?” she asked.

He blinked, trying to centre the room around him. Damn it all, his head hurt. 

“What were you thinking?” he snapped. “Who closes their eyes during a training session?!”

“S-sorry! I got a little excited…”

Excited? 

“Don’t be sorry. Do better next time.”

“Next time?”

“Tomorrow. We’ll meet again tomorrow.”

Uraraka’s eyes lit up, that same smile widening until it hurt his cheeks to look at it. Katsuki’s heart gave a long and nauseating leap. 

He squeezed her shoulder. “That was a damn good kick,” he praised. “My head is spinning.”

Uraraka’s face ignited like fireworks, those pink cheeks glowing with an amalgam of embarrassment and pride. She rubbed the back of her head, still grinning without a care in the world.

“Let’s give it one more try,” he said. 

Still grinning, Uraraka stepped back into place. Katsuki stated at her, caught in the trance of his own rapid heartbeat. She was glowing. 

“I’ll do my best!”

Katsuki now knew what they meant by “seeing stars”.
trail.content_abstract:
Series: Boku no Hero Academia
Setting: Canon.
Pairing: Kacchako. 

Summary: They say the way to a man’s heart… is through a kick to the head?! 

A/N: I’m pretty behind on the manga right now so I went with a post-internship setting inspired by an experience I had in one of my martial arts classes ^^’  

Uraraka had been training for hours. Katsuki watched from his seat, tucked away behind a screen Yaoyorozu had decorated the lobby with. In order to make space, Uraraka had moved furniture, expanding the area to create a safe distance for combat. It was never his intention to hide, she’d simply overlooked him. 

In hindsight, Katsuki could have offered a hand, probably sped up the process. But then she’d managed on her own and it was too late to say anything about it. She wouldn’t be long, he’d thought. He’d just wait it out. And then suddenly it was curfew and every fibre of his being was itching—exploding—to leave. 

In the end, Katsuki just couldn’t bring himself to go. An out of body experience, one might say, or a genuine desire not to be labelled a pervert like that stupid Mineta. It didn’t matter how beautiful the girls in class were, they wanted to be heroes just like him. He valued strength, not appearance. They were rivals and equals and everything in between. Nothing more; nothing less.

(By any chance does anyone know where i can get a full reference of a shiketsu uniform?…for science.)

Edit: if you have any Ocs you would be okay with me drawing then please feel free to tell me! I like hearing about other people’s wonderful Ocs and love it even more when i get to draw them👌
